study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the utility of a novel sunscreen containing DNA-photolyase for treating cutaneous field cancerization (CFC) and actinic keratoses (AK).
results_summary: The study found a 100% partial response rate, with all subjects showing at least a 50% reduction in AK lesions and an overall 76.6% reduction in lesion count. No adverse events were reported.
population_specificity: Nine subjects (mean age 70.6 years, male:female ratio 5:4) with CFC/AK.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to measure the effect of two water-resistant sunscreens on local sweat production during exercise in the heat and compare these effects to an antiperspirant.
results_summary: The inorganic physical sun block (sunscreen B) significantly reduced sweat rate similar to an antiperspirant, while the organic chemical sun filter (sunscreen A) did not differ from the no-lotion control. The study concluded that sunscreen B hindered sweating as much as an antiperspirant, but the specific ingredient responsible was not identified.
population_specificity: 20 physically active, healthy college students (10 men and 10 women).
effective_dosage: Not specified (application method implied standard sunscreen use).
study_duration: 2 exercise sessions on consecutive days, each lasting 20 minutes.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop a safe, non-photocatalytic sunscreen filter using iron-substituted hydroxyapatite (HAp) derived from cod fish bones, with improved UV absorption properties.
results_summary: The study found that iron-substituted HAp, particularly when treated with Fe(II) chloride under basic pH and processed via high-energy ball milling, showed superior UV protection (SPF up to 4.1 higher than control) and broad-spectrum coverage (λcrit >370nm, UVA/UVB ratio close to 1). The sunscreen was also non-photocatalytic, posing no environmental threat, and exhibited synergistic effects when combined with other filters like titanium dioxide.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro or material study, no human subjects mentioned).
effective_dosage: Not specified (material preparation methods described, but no dosage for human use provided).
study_duration: Not specified (study focused on material synthesis and testing, not longitudinal application).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the efficacy and tolerability of a topical formulation combining piroxicam and sunscreen in treating actinic keratosis (A.K.).
results_summary: The study found that the topical piroxicam and sunscreen formulation significantly reduced A.K. lesions, with a -88% reduction in A.K.E.S.A. scores after 6 months and maintained efficacy 1 year post-treatment. Adverse events were limited to mild local irritation.
population_specificity: Thirty-eight subjects with a total of 69 A.K. lesions.
study_duration: 6 months of treatment followed by 12 months of follow-up.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy and safety of a combination treatment involving DAB and TGF-β1 biomimetic oligopeptide-68 with sunscreen for facial melasma, comparing it to hydroquinone cream.
results_summary: The combination treatment showed significant improvement in melasma by the 6th and 12th weeks, with most subjects reporting moderate improvement and no severe adverse reactions. The treatment was superior to hydroquinone in pigment reduction.
population_specificity: 40 females with facial melasma (38 completed the study).
effective_dosage: DAB serum at night and DAB/TGF-β1 biomimetic oligopeptide-68/sunscreen cream in the morning and at noon (specific amounts not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the degradation efficiency and mechanism of the sunscreen agent PABA using the UV/Fe(2+)/persulphate method.
results_summary: Over 99% of PABA was degraded into CO2 and H2O, with SO4 (·-) radicals showing greater effects on degradation; natural anions impeded degradation.
population_specificity: Not specified (laboratory study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify predictors of occupational sunscreen use among US Hispanic adults working outdoors.
results_summary: The study found that 69% of participants rarely or never used sunscreen while working outdoors. Factors like being female, higher education, and residing at higher latitudes were associated with more frequent sunscreen use.
population_specificity: US Hispanic adults working outdoors (n = 149, 85% male).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether sunscreen formulations could serve as additional water barriers to mitigate stratum corneum disruption caused by prolonged water exposure.
results_summary: Sunscreen application helped repel water at the skin surface, reducing water-induced barrier disruption and statistically decreasing irritation in an acute patch test model.
population_specificity: Not specified (likely general population engaging in water activities).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the potential of plants (specifically hairy root cultures of Armoracia rusticana) to degrade oxybenzone (OBZ), a common UV filter in sunscreens, through phytoremediation.
results_summary: The study found that hairy root cultures eliminated over 20% of spiked OBZ (100μM) within 3 hours, identifying two metabolites (OBZ-Glu and OBZ-Mal-Glu) formed through enzymatic processes. The results suggest plants can metabolize OBZ via glucosylation and malonylation, with OBZ-Glu excreted into the medium and OBZ-Mal-Glu stored in root cells.
population_specificity: Hairy root cultures of Armoracia rusticana (horseradish).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the degradation pathway of sunscreen active ingredients (EHMC and MCA) in the presence of sodium hypochlorite (NaOCl) and UV radiation.
results_summary: The study found that EHMC and MCA degrade into various chlorinated breakdown products when exposed to HOCl, with C=C bridge cleavage being a primary reaction. UV radiation surprisingly reduced the formation of breakdown products compared to non-UV treatment.
population_specificity: Not applicable (in vitro chemical analysis)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine how processes of change and decisional balance influence sun protection behaviors, including sunscreen use, in individuals at different stages of behavior change.
results_summary: The study found that processes of change significantly predicted the pros of sun protection, which in turn predicted improved sun avoidance and sunscreen use. Mediation analyses supported the role of underlying risk cognitions in enhancing sun protection adherence.
population_specificity: Individuals in the precontemplation (N = 964) and preparation (N = 463) stages of behavior change.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a self-regulatory intervention focusing on planning sunscreen use was more effective than standard education in improving sunscreen use, and whether motivation levels influenced outcomes.
results_summary: The self-regulatory intervention improved planning but not direct sunscreen use; planning mediated the effect on later sunscreen use. Less motivated participants benefited more from the intervention.
population_specificity: College students (N = 253)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop effective methods for characterizing titanium dioxide (TiO2) and zinc oxide (ZnO) nanoparticles in sunscreen sprays, including their size, shape, composition, and aggregation/agglomeration properties.
results_summary: The study demonstrated that transmission electron microscopy (TEM) coupled with a window-type microchip K-kit and X-ray diffraction (XRD) effectively characterized oxide nanoparticles in sunscreen sprays, with strong correlation between XRD and TEM measurements. The methods provided consistent data on nanoparticle interactions in formulations without altering sample properties.
population_specificity: Not specified (focused on sunscreen spray formulations).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the environmental and potential health risks of Benzophenone-3 (BP-3) in sunscreens, focusing on its physicochemical properties, toxicokinetics, and ecological impact.
results_summary: BP-3 is lipophilic, bioaccumulative, and rapidly absorbed, with metabolites showing greater estrogenic potency. It has been detected in various environmental and human samples, with potential endocrine-disrupting effects, though ambient water levels are generally below predicted no-effect concentrations.
population_specificity: Aquatic ecosystems and human populations (urine, serum, breast milk, placental tissues).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to test the efficacy of a topical sunscreen in preventing UV-induced effects on nevi compared to a physical barrier.
results_summary: Both physical barriers and sunscreens partially prevented UV-B effects on nevi, but subclinical UV radiation effects still occurred. Sunscreens were less effective than physical barriers in preventing inflammatory UV-B-induced effects.
population_specificity: Twenty-three nevi from 20 patients attending a referral hospital.
study_duration: Single dose of UV-B irradiation, with evaluation 7 days later.

study_goal: To determine if broad-spectrum sunscreen with anti-inflammatory agents reduces post-inflammatory hyperpigmentation (PIH) after fractional CO2 laser skin resurfacing when applied starting on the first day post-treatment.
results_summary: The study found that sunscreen with anti-inflammatory agents significantly reduced melanin index (indicating less PIH) at 1-week post-treatment compared to the control side. No significant differences were observed in transepidermal water loss or erythema index.
population_specificity: 30 Asian patients undergoing fractional CO2 laser skin resurfacing (26 completed follow-up).
effective_dosage: Broad-spectrum sunscreen with anti-inflammatory agents applied in the morning, plus petrolatum ointment four times daily.
study_duration: 1 week of active intervention, with follow-up for 3 months.

study_goal: To determine whether regular use of sunscreen compared with discretionary use or β-carotene supplements compared with placebo retard skin aging, measured by degree of photoaging.
results_summary: Regular sunscreen use showed no detectable increase in skin aging after 4.5 years and was 24% less than in the discretionary sunscreen group. β-Carotene supplementation had no overall effect on skin aging.
population_specificity: 903 adults younger than 55 years from Nambour, Australia.
effective_dosage: Daily use of broad-spectrum sunscreen (specific SPF not mentioned).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the UV tolerance of Klebsormidium fluitans strains and their capability to synthesize mycosporine-like amino acids (MAAs) as potential sunscreen compounds.
results_summary: The study found that K. fluitans strains exhibited high UV tolerance, with the ability to synthesize and accumulate a putative MAA, especially under UV-B exposure, supporting its function as a UV sunscreen. Strain-specific differences in MAA accumulation were observed, but these did not correlate with the altitude of the sampling locations.
population_specificity: Klebsormidium fluitans strains isolated from aeroterrestrial biofilms and biological soil crusts in the Tyrolean and South Tyrolean Alps (600–2350 m elevation).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess skin absorption characteristics of sunscreens (specifically oxybenzone) following fractional CO2 laser treatment.
results_summary: The fractional laser had a negligible effect on modulating oxybenzone absorption, suggesting minimal impact on sunscreen efficacy post-treatment. Skin histology and drug absorption returned to normal within 2-3 days.
population_specificity: Nude mice (animal model)
study_duration: Single irradiation, effects monitored for 2-3 days

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify attitudes, personal characteristics, and barriers associated with sunscreen use among collegiate athletes, a high-risk population for UV exposure.
results_summary: While 96% of athletes agreed sunscreen helps prevent skin cancer, over 50% never used it, and 75% used it 3 or fewer days per week. Predictors of sunscreen use included female gender, recent sunburns, perceived skin cancer risk, knowing someone with skin cancer, and concerns about wrinkles or sunburns.
population_specificity: Collegiate athletes (290 participants from Duke and Stanford Universities).
study_duration: Survey conducted from April 2010 to June 2011 (2 months).

study_goal: The researchers sought to understand perceptions of sun protection and skin cancer risk among Hispanic communities and assess differences in sunscreen availability across neighborhoods with varying ethnic compositions.
results_summary: The study found that stores in Hispanic neighborhoods had fewer sunscreen options compared to non-Hispanic White neighborhoods, and barriers to sunscreen use included economic factors and misconceptions about skin cancer risk.
population_specificity: 65 adult Spanish-speaking Hispanics (ages 23-72) recruited from faith-based institutions in Chicago.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of different psychological interventions (resource communication vs. planning) on promoting sunscreen use across different stages of behavioral change.
results_summary: The study found no overall treatment effects on planning but identified an interaction between time, stage of change, and intervention type. Resource communication was more effective for pre-intenders (no intention to use sunscreen), while planning interventions worked better for intenders (high intention but no regular use).
population_specificity: 292 participants categorized into pre-intenders (51), intenders (102), and actors (139) based on their stage of sunscreen use.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify factors influencing sun-protective behaviors (including sunscreen use) in organ transplant recipients to improve overall sunscreen adoption.
results_summary: Sunscreen use increased post-transplantation, with factors like sex, skin type, healthcare provider advice, and pre-transplantation sunscreen habits significantly influencing post-transplantation behavior. Sun avoidance also improved, linked to pre-transplantation sun exposure and clinician advice.
population_specificity: U.S. organ transplant recipients (198 participants) without prior skin cancer diagnosis (2004–2008).

study_goal: The researchers sought to determine whether increased sunscreen availability would lead to greater sunscreen use among outdoor collegiate athletes.
results_summary: Athletes with sunscreen placed in their locker rooms and golf bags showed significantly greater sunscreen use (1.13 more days per week) and a non-significant 20% increase in reapplication during competitions. No change in reapplication was observed during practice.
population_specificity: NCAA Division IA female golf team athletes (n = 83).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the cost-effectiveness and health benefits of promoting sunscreen use for preventing skin cancers, including melanoma, in white populations residing in sunny settings.
results_summary: The study found that promoting sunscreen use was cost-effective, preventing 33 melanomas, 168 cutaneous squamous-cell carcinomas, and 4 melanoma deaths over the cohort's lifetime, with a 64% likelihood of cost-effectiveness at a willingness-to-pay threshold of AU$50,000 per quality-adjusted life-year gained.
population_specificity: White populations living in sunny environments (specifically Australia).
study_duration: Lifetime projection (intervention duration not explicitly stated)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare a motivational approach with a volitional planning and self-efficacy intervention to improve regular sunscreen use.
results_summary: The volitional intervention improved sunscreen use, with coping planning identified as the key mediator for this effect at the final assessment. The findings highlight the importance of coping planning in sun protection interventions.
population_specificity: 205 women with a mean age of 25 years.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the pharmacokinetics and potential synergistic effects of concurrent topical application of DEET and oxybenzone, including their permeation, distribution, and toxicity.
results_summary: The study found that combined DEET and oxybenzone application increased skin permeation and systemic distribution but did not increase hepatotoxicity. Both compounds accumulated in blood, liver, and kidney, with accelerated disappearance from the application site and reduced elimination half-lives.
population_specificity: Male Sprague-Dawley rats
effective_dosage: Topical application of 100 mg/kg DEET and 40 mg/kg OBZ; intravenous administration of 2 mg/kg DEET or OBZ

study_goal: The researchers aimed to measure the thickness at which primary schoolchildren apply sunscreen and compare it to the standard testing thickness (2.00 mg/cm²), while also examining the influence of age and dispenser type.
results_summary: Children applied sunscreen at a median thickness of 0.48 mg/cm², significantly less than the standard testing thickness. Application thickness varied by dispenser type, with the pump (0.75 mg/cm²) and squeeze bottle (0.57 mg/cm²) yielding thicker application than the roll-on (0.22 mg/cm²).
population_specificity: Children aged 5-12 years (grades 1-7) from public primary schools in Queensland, Australia.
effective_dosage: Not specified (application thickness measured in mg/cm²).
study_duration: 3 consecutive school weeks (Monday-Friday) per dispenser type.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review legislation and guidelines related to sun protection measures, including sunscreen, across G7 countries, Australia, and New Zealand to assess gaps and make recommendations for reducing skin cancer rates.
results_summary: The study found limited legislative support for sun protection measures, with only Australia and select jurisdictions implementing significant policies like tanning bed bans and sunscreen tax exemptions. Workplace and recreational UVR exposure protections were largely absent outside Australia and New Zealand.
population_specificity: G7 countries, Australia, and New Zealand (focus on general populations, outdoor workers, and youth).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether sunscreen use affects vitamin D status, considering photoprotection and public health perspectives.
results_summary: The study concluded that sunscreen use for daily and recreational photoprotection does not compromise vitamin D synthesis, even under optimal conditions. However, patients with photosensitivity disorders using high-protection sunscreens and other protective measures may need vitamin D screening and supplementation.
population_specificity: Healthy individuals and patients with photosensitivity disorders.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the balance between the benefits of mild UVB exposure (vitamin D production, immune modulation, blood pressure reduction) and the risks of excessive UVB exposure (skin damage, aging, cancer), particularly in the context of sunscreen use.
results_summary: The study found that mild UVB exposure is sufficient for maintaining adequate vitamin D levels and other health benefits, even with high-SPF sunscreen use, though excessive protection (SPF 50+) may slightly reduce vitamin D production. It also highlighted UVB's role in immune regulation and cardiovascular health.
population_specificity: General population, with mentions of dark-skinned individuals and those with varying sun exposure habits.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the role of photolyases in supplementing sunscreen to enhance DNA repair and slow carcinogenesis caused by UV radiation.
results_summary: The study found that photolyases, when used in topical agents, can repair UV-induced DNA damage and influence the early stages of carcinogenesis, augmenting the incomplete protection offered by traditional sunscreens.
population_specificity: Not specified in the abstract.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the prevalence and determinants of vitamin D deficiency in pregnant women in Switzerland, including the role of sunscreen use as a potential factor.
results_summary: The study found that sunscreen use, while not individually significant, collectively improved the model's ability to explain vitamin D status in pregnant women. Low vitamin D levels were common among participants and their newborns.
population_specificity: Pregnant women in their third trimester from three Swiss centers (Zurich, Bellinzona, and Samedan).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the photoprotective properties of Polypodium leucotomos (PL) extracts as an adjunct to sunscreen, focusing on antioxidant, immunoregulatory, anti-inflammatory, and antitumorigenic effects.
results_summary: PL supplementation enhances endogenous antioxidant systems, reduces UV-mediated oxidative DNA mutations, accelerates removal of UV-induced photoproducts, and shows protective effects against photoaging and PUVA-induced phototoxicity. It also demonstrates potential in preventing skin cancer by reducing UV-induced inflammatory responses and inhibiting extracellular matrix remodeling.
population_specificity: Not specified (general photoprotection context).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the prevalence of 25-hydroxyvitamin D insufficiency/deficiency in pediatric HCT patients and compare it to healthy controls, while also evaluating factors like sunscreen use and vitamin D supplementation.
results_summary: The study found that pediatric HCT patients had significantly lower 25-hydroxyvitamin D levels than healthy controls, with most being insufficient or deficient. Few patients in either group reported sunscreen use or adequate vitamin D supplementation.
population_specificity: Pediatric patients undergoing allogeneic hematopoietic cell transplant (HCT) and healthy pediatric controls.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the Vitamin D status in athletes and the potential influence of factors like sunscreen use, without defining the need or optimal amount of supplementation.
results_summary: The study found that little is known about Vitamin D status in athletes, with factors like sunscreen use potentially influencing levels, but the need for supplementation remains unclear. Measurement methods for Vitamin D lack standardization, leading to inconsistent results.
population_specificity: Athletes

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the relationship between photoprotection measures (including sunscreen use) and vitamin D levels, particularly in individuals with skin cancer.
results_summary: The study found no significant relationship between adherence to photoprotection measures (sunscreen, clothing, hats, etc.) and serum 25(OH)D levels. Oral vitamin D supplementation, but not dietary intake, was associated with higher vitamin D levels, though vitamin D insufficiency was prevalent in the study population.
population_specificity: Subjects with skin cancer

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether sun avoidance and sunscreen use affect vitamin D levels and to provide recommendations for adequate vitamin D intake.
results_summary: The study found that regular sunscreen use is not associated with vitamin D insufficiency, and adequate vitamin D intake is linked to reduced risks of various health issues, including bone fractures, certain cancers, and cardiovascular disease. Intentional UV exposure is discouraged as a means to obtain vitamin D.
population_specificity: Patients at risk for vitamin D insufficiency (general population, with consideration of skin type).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to improve the hydrophobicity of purple sweet potato (PSP)-based intelligent packaging films using stearic acid coating and heat pressing treatments.
results_summary: The study found that stearic acid coating reduced hydrophilicity but also decreased transparency, mechanical properties, and color changeability. Heat pressing improved transparency and mechanical properties, with color changeability dependent on the temperature used (100 °C preserved color changeability, while 150 °C eliminated it).
population_specificity: Not applicable (in vitro study on packaging films).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of substituting concentrate mix (CM) with sweet potato vine (SPV) on growth performance, carcass characteristics, and methane production in rams.
results_summary: Substituting CM with SPV did not affect body weight gain, feed intake, or feed conversion ratio but reduced in vitro methane production. SPV substitution showed mixed effects on carcass characteristics and metabolizable energy, with higher methane reduction at 40% SPV replacement.
population_specificity: Forty yearling rams with an initial body weight of 18.5 ± 0.7 kg.
effective_dosage: CM replaced with SPV at 10%, 20%, 30%, and 40% (385 g/head/day CM for control).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine how repeated freezing-thawing treatment followed by carboxymethylation modifies sweet potato starch's structure and physicochemical properties.
results_summary: Freezing-thawing pretreatment enhanced carboxymethylation, leading to structural changes that improved water solubility, paste transparency, retrogradation, and viscoelasticity. The modified starch showed higher substitution degree and reaction efficiency compared to untreated starch.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro study on sweet potato starch)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to characterize a newly identified rolD-like gene in sweet potato and investigate its role in stress response mechanisms and potential contribution to the crop's resilience.
results_summary: The study found that the rolD-like gene encodes a protein with ornithine cyclodeaminase activity, is upregulated by stress and methyl jasmonate, and enhances proline accumulation. Overexpression in Arabidopsis led to altered flowering and stress tolerance traits, suggesting its role in sweet potato's abiotic stress resilience.
population_specificity: Arabidopsis thaliana (model organism) and in vitro assays

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine how different cover crops (hairy vetch and rapeseed) influence soil microbial communities, soil properties, and sweet potato yield under red soil dryland conditions.
results_summary: Rapeseed treatment did not significantly increase sweet potato yield but showed an 8.49% increase rate. Resource-conservative cover crops (like rapeseed) improved soil properties (pH, SOC, TP) and bacterial diversity, while resource-acquisitive cover crops (like hairy vetch) promoted specific microbial groups and enhanced community stability.
population_specificity: Sweet potato cultivation under red soil dryland conditions.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine how exogenous melatonin (MT) enhances heat tolerance in sweet potato by mitigating oxidative stress and regulating gene expression.
results_summary: MT treatment reduced oxidative stress markers (hydrogen peroxide, superoxide ions, MDA) and modulated genes involved in redox regulation, nicotinate metabolism, and hormone signaling (e.g., MPK3, ERF), improving heat tolerance.
population_specificity: Sweet potato plants under heat stress conditions.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the cytotoxicity of prodelphinidin (PD), an anthocyanin found in purple sweet potato, in human triple-negative breast cancer (TNBC) cells.
results_summary: PD selectively inhibited TNBC cell proliferation and induced apoptosis through ROS activation and endoplasmic reticulum stress, with dose- and time-dependent effects. PD also downregulated Bcl-2, activated caspase-3/9, and cleaved PARP, while increasing ROS production and reducing SOD activity.
population_specificity: Human MDA-MB-231 and MDA-MB-436 triple-negative breast cancer cells.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if terahertz spectroscopy could rapidly and non-destructively assess starch digestibility in white sweet potato after acid hydrolysis and heat-moisture treatment (HMT).
results_summary: The study found strong correlations between specific terahertz peaks and rapidly digestible starch (RDS) and resistant starch (RS) content, indicating that terahertz spectroscopy can effectively determine starch digestibility in treated white sweet potato.
population_specificity: White sweet potato starch treated with acetic acid, citric acid, and HMT.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify novel anti-leukemia agents from sweet potato by analyzing its flavonoid content and validating their effects on acute myeloid leukemia (AML).
results_summary: Sweet potato leaves, particularly from Nanshu 017, had the highest flavonoid content (2.27% DW). Cynaroside, nepitrin, and yuanhuanin were identified as potential anti-leukemia agents, showing significant inhibition of AML cell growth in vitro and in vivo.
population_specificity: In vitro and in vivo models of acute myeloid leukemia (AML).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify genes and miRNAs involved in sweet potato tuberous root development and assess the role of auxin signaling in this process.
results_summary: The study identified 29,633 differentially expressed genes and 510 miRNAs associated with tuberous root development, with auxin treatment significantly increasing yield. Key miRNA-target pairs (miR319-TCP4 and miR172-AP2) were validated, confirming their role in root tuber development.
population_specificity: Sweet potato plants (no human or animal subjects).
effective_dosage: Not specified (exogenous auxin treatment mentioned but dosage not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of heat-moisture treatment (HMT) on sweet potato starch (SPS) properties and structures during gelatinization.
results_summary: HMT increased the gelatinization temperature of SPS to 82.55°C, improved viscoelasticity in later gelatinization stages (S3-S6), reduced particle size, and enhanced the ordering degree of starch structure. The study also observed the destruction of the original crystalline structure and formation of a layered recrystallized structure during gelatinization.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro study on starch properties)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of substituting sweet potato leaf meal (SPLM) in broiler chicken diets on performance, blood indices, carcass characteristics, and histopathology.
results_summary: The study found that 7.5% SPLM (T3) improved weight gain, feed conversion ratio (FCR), and carcass quality, while higher levels (up to 15%) reduced production costs and serum cholesterol. No tissue damage was observed, but histopathology showed significant effects on the heart and liver at 15% SPLM.
population_specificity: Cobb-500 strain broiler finisher chickens (720-day-old).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the protective effect of purple sweet potato polysaccharide (PSP) on lipopolysaccharide-induced acute lung injury (ALI) in mice and lung epithelial A549 cells, as well as its mechanism and subacute toxicity.
results_summary: PSP significantly reduced markers of lung injury, inflammation, and apoptosis while increasing protective factors like SOD. It also showed no apparent adverse effects in mice.
population_specificity: ICR mice and lung epithelial A549 cells

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the quality changes in sweet potato-oat composite dough during freeze-thaw cycles, focusing on ice crystal formation and protein alterations.
results_summary: Freeze-thaw cycles reduced dough elasticity and viscosity, increased hardness, and degraded sensory and structural quality, making it unsuitable for use after more than three cycles. Ice crystal formation disrupted water status and protein structure, leading to pore enlargement and collapse.
population_specificity: Sweet potato-oat composite dough (in vitro study, no human participants).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the antioxidant, anti-inflammatory, and anti-osteoporotic activities of Maejo 341 Sweet Potato (MSP) peel and flesh extracts, as well as their anthocyanin content.
results_summary: MSP peel extracts showed greater antioxidant capacity, suppressed inflammation by inhibiting proinflammatory cytokines and enzymes, and reduced oxidative stress while enhancing osteoblast viability. The extracts also inhibited osteoclastogenic pathways, suggesting potential benefits for osteoporosis.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro or animal study implied by methods).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the biological activity and probiotic properties of lactic acid bacteria (LAB) isolated from sweet potato stalk kimchi.
results_summary: Four LAB strains showed high bile acid and pH resistance, antimicrobial activity against E. coli and Salmonella Typhimurium, and antioxidative potential, with SPK2 exhibiting the highest antioxidative effects. These strains demonstrated potential as probiotics with strong antibacterial effects.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro study on bacterial strains).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the effects of various heat treatments on sweet potato flour's physicochemical properties, functionality, and starch digestibility, and to develop meal replacement flours based on these findings.
results_summary: Heat treatments altered color, solubility, swelling power, and starch digestibility of sweet potato flour, with baking, frying, and microwaving increasing rapidly digestible starch, while steaming reduced slowly digestible starch. Two meal replacement flours (SP-1 and SP-2) were successfully developed, showing good brewing properties and shear-thinning behavior.
population_specificity: Not specified (likely in vitro or lab-based study)

study_goal: The study aimed to identify predictors affecting vitamin D status in postmenopausal women, including factors like sunscreen use.
results_summary: The study found that sunscreen use was one of several factors predisposing postmenopausal women to vitamin D deficiency, but it did not specifically evaluate sunscreen's efficacy or safety.
population_specificity: Postmenopausal women aged 51 to 78 from 13 nations.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of purple sweet potato polysaccharide (PSPP) supplementation on production performance, egg quality, jejunal morphology, and gut microbiota in laying hens.
results_summary: PSPP altered gut microbiota (increasing Firmicutes and decreasing Bacteroidota) but did not affect jejunal morphology, laying performance, or egg quality. Yolk color showed a linear decrease with PSPP supplementation.
population_specificity: 288 Hy-line Brown laying hens (23 weeks old)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine how different thermal treatments (steaming, frying, baking) affect the physicochemical structure, antioxidant properties, and hypoglycemic activities of sweet potato polysaccharides.
results_summary: The study found that thermal processing did not significantly alter the functional groups, chemical bonding, or bioactivities (antioxidant and hypoglycemic) of sweet potato polysaccharides, which remained dose-dependent in their effects.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro or ex vivo study implied).
study_duration: Single treatment (20 min steaming, 10 min frying, 30 min baking).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate sweet potato's response to Cadmium (Cd) stress and its potential for use in Cd-polluted agricultural land.
results_summary: Cd stress inhibited sweet potato growth, photosynthesis, and carbohydrate accumulation, while increasing antioxidant enzyme activity and Cd accumulation in plant organs, with tuberous roots showing lower Cd accumulation.
population_specificity: Sweet potato plants (no human subjects).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the biocontrol efficacy of Paecilomyces lilacinus CS-Z and Bacillus pumilus Y-26 against stem nematodes in sweet potato and their impact on rhizosphere bacterial communities.
results_summary: B.pumilus Y-26 and P.lilacinus CS-Z showed suppression rates of 82.9% and 85.1% against stem nematodes, respectively, while also promoting plant growth and increasing beneficial rhizosphere microorganisms like Gaiella, Bacillus, and Streptomyces. The nematicide fosthiazate had minimal impact on bacterial communities.
population_specificity: Sweet potato plants affected by stem nematodes (Ditylenchus destructor Thorne).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of four pre-frying treatments on the chemical composition, anthocyanins, acrylamide levels, and digestive behavior of purple sweet potato deep-fried chips.
results_summary: Pretreatments (soaking, blanching, PEF, and PEFB) affected fat and starch content, with blanching and PEFB increasing fat absorption and breaking starch into maltodextrins. Anthocyanins were significantly reduced in treated chips, while acrylamide levels varied, with PEFB-treated chips showing the lowest levels. Anthocyanin bioaccessibility was highest in soaked chips (66.57–92.88%).
population_specificity: Not specified (laboratory study on sweet potato chips).
effective_dosage: Not specified (15 independent batches, three per treatment).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop a new method for determining esters in the glycerol phase of biodiesel production to minimize biodiesel losses.
results_summary: The study introduced a gradient RP-LC method that is reliable, faster, and capable of differentiating esters of higher fatty acids in the glycerol phase, outperforming existing methods like isocratic HPLC and GC.
population_specificity: Not applicable (laboratory-based analysis)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the mechanisms behind elevated blood pressure following consumption of repeatedly heated vegetable oil.
results_summary: Repeatedly heated soy oil significantly increased blood pressure, altered plasma enzyme levels, and impaired vascular reactivity compared to fresh oil and control groups. The effects were linked to changes in endothelium-dependent and independent factors regulating blood pressure.
population_specificity: Male Sprague-Dawley rats (42 total, divided into six groups).
effective_dosage: Not specified (diet containing fresh or heated soy oil).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if a vegetable-oil emulsion in a meal replacement could aid weight maintenance and reduce body fat mass after initial weight loss.
results_summary: The study found no significant difference in weight loss between the vegetable-oil and control groups, but the vegetable-oil group showed a greater reduction in body fat mass (1.7% vs. 0.8%).
population_specificity: Subjects who lost >5% body weight after a 6-week very low calorie diet.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review and analyze existing studies on the appetite suppressant effects of a vegetable oil emulsion, investigating methodological differences that may explain inconsistent findings.
results_summary: The meta-analysis found a small but inconsistent appetite suppressant effect of the vegetable oil emulsion, with significant heterogeneity between studies. The only consistent finding was a lack of effect on food intake 4 hours post-treatment in studies conducted after 2003.
population_specificity: Not specified (general population inferred from available studies).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of specific yeast strains in treating high-strength vegetable oil-containing wastewater and identify key factors influencing yeast strain selection.
results_summary: The SBR system achieved stable removal of >89% COD and >99% oil, with Candida lipolytica, Candida tropicalis, and Candida halophila emerging as dominant strains. Hydrophobicity and emulsification ability were identified as critical factors for yeast strain selection in oil-containing wastewater treatment.
population_specificity: Yeast strains in a sequencing batch reactor (SBR) system for wastewater treatment.
effective_dosage: Wastewater containing 15 g/L COD and 10 g/L oil.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop a rapid and accurate method for quantifying total brominated vegetable oil (BVO) in soft drinks using ion chromatography.
results_summary: The study successfully developed a method with high recovery rates (92.5-98.5%), linear calibration curves (r² = 0.998), and low variability (CV < 5%). It detected BVO in commercial soft drinks at concentrations ranging from 1.8 to 14.510 mg/l.
population_specificity: Commercial soft drinks (no human subjects studied).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the use of rapeseed oil as a safer alternative to toxic organic solvents in the synthesis of manganese zinc ferrite nanoparticles.
results_summary: The study found that rapeseed oil effectively replaced toxic solvents in nanoparticle synthesis, resulting in phase-pure ferrite with improved magnetization after heat treatment. The heat-treated nanoparticles showed significantly higher spontaneous magnetization (24.1 emu/g) compared to as-prepared nanoparticles (1.81 emu/g).
population_specificity: Not applicable (in vitro study)
study_duration: Heat treatment was conducted for 3 hours at 300 °C.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the biogeochemical effects of emulsified vegetable oil (EVO) in a uranium-contaminated aquifer to assess its potential for enhancing uranium reduction and immobilization.
results_summary: The study found that EVO hydrolysis in the field was faster than in lab microcosms, leading to the precipitation of long-chain fatty acids with calcium, which acted as a secondary electron donor source. The model predicted significant accumulation of denitrifying and sulfate-reducing bacteria and U(IV) precipitates, particularly near injection wells and treatment zone boundaries, enhancing U(VI) reduction.
population_specificity: Uranium-contaminated aquifer (environmental study, not human subjects).
study_duration: Over a year of monitoring post-injection.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to document a rare case of acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) induced by lipoid pneumonia following near-drowning in vegetable oil.
results_summary: The study found that massive exposure to vegetable oil via near-drowning led to severe hypoxia, ARDS, and prolonged elevation of pulmonary vascular permeability, requiring intensive treatment with pulsed steroids and mechanical ventilation.
population_specificity: A 66-year-old woman who nearly drowned in a vat of vegetable oil.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of two major trans 18:1 isomers (elaidic acid and vaccenic acid) from partially hydrogenated vegetable oil on plasma lipid biomarkers of coronary heart disease risk.
results_summary: The PHVO diet increased plasma lipid ratios linked to CHD risk, while EA and VA treatments reduced these ratios, indicating improved CHD risk profiles. EA also inhibited liver lipid biosynthesis pathways, suggesting distinct metabolic effects compared to PHVO.
population_specificity: Male Golden Syrian hamsters

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the composting process of sludge from vegetable oil processing mixed with household waste, focusing on physico-chemical changes and biodegradation.
results_summary: The study found significant reductions in lipids (81% and 72%) and polyphenols (75% and 76%) in the compost mixtures, alongside increased humic acid content (22 and 36 mg/g). FTIR spectroscopy confirmed biodegradation of aliphatic compounds and increased aromatic structures, with M1 showing greater maturity than M2.
population_specificity: Sludge from a sewage treatment plant processing crude vegetable oil (Lesieur-Cristal, Morocco) mixed with household waste.
